channel.title: Ninite
channel.description:
Some of you may have heard of this great piece of software (yes i put this in a hardware section, someone should rename it to hardware & software)
[img]http://ninite.com/static/screenshots/ninite.jpg[/img]
basically, you visit the website: https://ninite.com/
tick each application you want, it will download and install them all, silently (with the best settings, like no installation of toolbars etc)
perfect after you have just reformatted your PC, theres about 20 programs here which are very useful.
I'm currently backing up my C drive as we speak, then will reformat and going to try this out.
EDIT: ok i just installed win7, after about 10 mins heres how it's going
[img]http://i47.tinypic.com/28vsl5d.jpg[/img]

item.title: Ninite
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:23, topic:343908”][quote author=la­wl link=topic=440292.msg3239169#msg3239169 date=1276745429]

Microsoft updates all its software (office etc.) through windows update.

Also you have to apply some updates, restart, apply more updates, restart, repeat the latter about 1000x until you are fully up to date. Any package manager updates EVERYTHING without needing to restart in between.

ive never had to do that :S
[/quote]

I’m talking about windows XP, Vista, and 7. I’ve had to do it with all of them.[/quote]
i’ve never had to do it with XP though

Read full topic

item.title: Ninite
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:23, topic:343908”][quote author=la­wl link=topic=440292.msg3239169#msg3239169 date=1276745429]

Microsoft updates all its software (office etc.) through windows update.

When using ubuntu i’ve had it require me to restart my computer while doing package updates. But that was about 2 years ago so maybe things have changed.
Also you have to apply some updates, restart, apply more updates, restart, repeat the latter about 1000x until you are fully up to date. Any package manager updates EVERYTHING without needing to restart in between.

ive never had to do that :S
[/quote]

I’m talking about windows XP, Vista, and 7. I’ve had to do it with all of them.[/quote]

Read full topic

Also you have to apply some updates, restart, apply more updates, restart, repeat the latter about 1000x until you are fully up to date. Any package manager updates EVERYTHING without needing to restart in between.
[/quote]
ive never had to do that :S[/quote]

I’m talking about windows XP, Vista, and 7. I’ve had to do it with all of them.

Read full topic

item.title: Ninite
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:20, topic:343908”][quote author=mwiebelhaus link=topic=440292.msg3237740#msg3237740 date=1276628863]
Microsoft updates all its software (office etc.) through windows update.
[/quote]

Also you have to apply some updates, restart, apply more updates, restart, repeat the latter about 1000x until you are fully up to date. Any package manager updates EVERYTHING without needing to restart in between.[/quote]

Maybe with older windows versions. Any updates I have installed in windows 7 all get installed and most without restart. I usually get them all installed when I shut down my computer for the night.

Read full topic

item.title: Ninite
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:17, topic:343908”][quote author=Unhandled link=topic=440292.msg3237760#msg3237760 date=1276630119]

Microsoft updates all its software (office etc.) through windows update.

If by update you mean fix critical bugs and security issues…Office 2007 isn’t going to update itself to 2010 through windows update, you’ll have to purchase it and uninstall 2007 then install 2010.
[/quote]
thats like going from kde 3 to kde 4[/quote]
which funnily enough can be done with a package manager…

Read full topic

item.title: Ninite
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Windows could really use a package manager, when I used to use it it was horribly painful trying to keep all your applications up to date.

I agree. The problem lies within the fact that it’s mostly proprietary software though.

Read full topic

item.title: Ninite
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“c|p, post:11, topic:343908”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=440292.msg3236540#msg3236540 date=1276528463]
Sounds sort of like a package manager. Does it handle updates too or not?
[/quote]

except it’s really not.
did you even look at it? you select some applications and it packs them in/with an installer stub and lets you download it.
it’s basically an sfx archive that’s just a little more convenient.[/quote]

I didn’t look at it, just read the first post. Windows could really use a package manager, when I used to use it it was horribly painful trying to keep all your applications up to date.

Read full topic

item.title: Ninite
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Sounds sort of like a package manager. Does it handle updates too or not?

except it’s really not.
did you even look at it? you select some applications and it packs them in/with an installer stub and lets you download it.
it’s basically an sfx archive that’s just a little more convenient.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Sounds sort of like a package manager. Does it handle updates too or not?

I’m guessing not because most of the programs I see their handle updates themselves, but I could be wrong because I haven’t used it before.

Read full topic

tick each application you want, it will download and install them all, silently (with the best settings, like no installation of toolbars etc)
